text: we just entered this age that we call
Big Data now this means that many
devices are producing data that we need
to process that we need to store that we
need to do something with and we want to
do this and then ever fast away you want
to have real-time information from all
these devices so there is a great demand
right now to have more data storage and
faster computation and so doing basic
research into what I sort of the limits
of this kind of computation data storage
i believe is very important for us to
really know how far we can drive this we
are here in one of the laboratories in
the IBM almaden research center in san
jose california in this laboratory we're
using very specialized tools to be able
to move atoms and to see atoms and to
work with atoms in order to do this we
have room full of electronic equipment
that we're in right now this is in the
end of the control room and then we
currently have two microscopes that are
controlled from this control room here
and that's where we actually have our
atoms that's where all the action is
really taking place so in order to
highlight the beauty and the fun that
you can have with being able to work
with atoms we figured it would be
fantastic to show something to the other
day audience that they can understand
that they can relate to and maybe get
them interested in to the science sort
of as a secondary thought and so we
created a movie called a boy and his
atom and in this movie we have two
characters the boy named Adam and his
atom as a friend and the atom finds the
boy they play together they jump
together they just interact with each
other and so it tells a very emotional
story very human story but based on
individual atoms every one of the frames
is made from you know a few atoms 100
atoms or so and so we rearrange those
atoms to tell a story in order to make a
movie we actually have to come up with a
design that shows the emotion of the
character Adam with very few atoms with
very few dots and so we hired
animation firm to come up with as few
dots as possible and still be able to
tell that story now let me put this in
perspective in my laboratory we created
242 individual frames and each one of
those frames contains on the order of
100 atoms or so in total we believe we
moved something on the order of five to
ten thousand atoms to make this movie
all by hand we don't have any automation
of it there's a large demand for for
data storage this demand is actually
increasing as we not only have have a
human created information but we have a
lot of information that is created by
video cameras and other equipment so
where as a very much increased demand
for data storage and so you might wonder
how many atoms does it take to do data
storage and that's kind of the questions
that we can answer my laboratory here
nowadays if you put information on a
very dense memory like the magnetic hard
disk that you have in your in your
computer then it takes on the order of 1
million atoms to store one bit of
information the bid is the basic basic
unit of information in 20 in the one and
all movies all everything is based on
being able to store these bits so it
takes about 1 million atoms now we
showed last year that we can actually
reduce that number to 12 we can store
the same information 1 bid on only 12
atoms so about 100,000 times smaller
this could have huge implications to 22
storage technologies if we could really
harness this in an everyday environment
then we could correspondingly store
100,000 times more information on the
same volume of space that means you know
instead of sewing one movie you could
store 100,000 movies on the same space I
think that we are as a society sort of
at the beginning of this computer
revolution then we will actually apply
computation too many many things that we
doubt nowadays maybe not even think
about so I think there is still a lot of
lot of space to explore both basic
science but also the technology with
technological
implications of this basic science
